Psalm 108:2	Rise up, my glory. Rise up, Psalter and harp. I will arise in early morning.
Psalm 108:3	I will confess to you, O Lord, among the peoples. And I will sing psalms to you among the nations.
Psalm 108:4	For your mercy is great, beyond the heavens, and your truth, even to the clouds.
Psalm 108:5	Be exalted, O God, beyond the heavens, and your glory, beyond all the earth,
Psalm 108:6	so that your beloved may be freed. Save with your right hand, and heed me.
Psalm 108:7	God has spoken in his holiness. I will exult, and I will divide Shechem, and I will divide by measure the steep valley of tabernacles.
Psalm 108:8	Gilead is mine, and Manasseh is mine, and Ephraim is the supporter of my head. Judah is my king.
Psalm 108:9	Moab is the cooking pot of my hope. I will extend my shoe in Idumea; the foreigners have become my friends.
Psalm 108:10	Who will lead me into the fortified city? Who will lead me, even into Idumea?
Psalm 108:11	Will not you, O God, who had rejected us? And will not you, O God, go out with our armies?
Psalm 108:12	Grant us help from tribulation, for vain is the help of man.
Psalm 108:13	In God, we will act virtuously, and he will bring our enemies to nothing.
Psalm 109:1	Unto the end. A Psalm of David.
Psalm 109:2	O God, do not be silent toward my praise, for the mouth of the sinner and the mouth of the deceitful one have been opened against me.
Psalm 109:3	They have spoken against me with deceitful tongues, and they have surrounded me with hateful words, and they fought against me over nothing.
Psalm 109:4	Instead of choosing to act on my behalf, they detracted me. But I gave myself to prayer.
Psalm 109:5	And they set evil against me, instead of good, and hatred, in return for my love.
Psalm 109:6	Establish the sinner over him, and let the devil stand at his right hand.
Psalm 109:7	When he is judged, may he go forth in condemnation, and may his prayer be counted as sin.
Psalm 109:8	May his days be few, and let another take his episcopate.
Psalm 109:9	May his sons be orphans, and his wife a widow.
Psalm 109:10	May his sons be carried by those who walk unsteadily, and may they go begging. And may they be cast out of their dwelling places.
Psalm 109:11	May the money lenders scrutinize all his belongings, and let foreigners plunder his labors.
Psalm 109:12	May there be no one to assist him, nor anyone to be compassionate to his orphaned children.
Psalm 109:13	May his posterity be in utter ruin. In one generation, may his name be wiped away.
Psalm 109:14	May the iniquity of his fathers return in memory before the sight of the Lord, and do not let the sin of his mother be wiped away.
Psalm 109:15	May these be opposite the Lord always, but let their memory perish from the earth.
Psalm 109:16	For certain things are not remembered about them, in order to be merciful.
Psalm 109:17	And so the destitute man was pursued, with the beggar and the remorseful in heart, so as to be put to death.
Psalm 109:18	And he loved a curse, and it came to him. And he was unwilling to have a blessing, and it went far from him. And he clothed himself with curses like a garment, and it entered his inner self like water, and it entered his bones like oil.
Psalm 109:19	May it be to him like a garment that covers him, and like a belt that always cinches him.
Psalm 109:20	This is the work of those who detract me with the Lord and who speak evils against my soul.
Psalm 109:21	But as for you, Lord, O Lord: act on my behalf for your name’s sake. For your mercy is sweet.
Psalm 109:22	Free me, for I am destitute and poor, and my heart has been disquieted within me.
Psalm 109:23	I have been taken away like a shadow when it declines, and I have been shaken off like locusts.
Psalm 109:24	My knees have been weakened by fasting, and my flesh has been replaced by oil.
Psalm 109:25	And I have become a disgrace to them. They saw me, and they shook their heads.
Psalm 109:26	Help me, O Lord, my God. Save me according to your mercy.
Psalm 109:27	And let them know that this is your hand, and that you, O Lord, have done this.
Psalm 109:28	They will curse, and you will bless. May those who rise up against me be confounded. But your servant will rejoice.
Psalm 109:29	May those who detract me be clothed with shame, and may they be covered with their confusion, as if with a double cloak.
Psalm 109:30	I will confess exceedingly to the Lord with my mouth. And I will praise him in the midst of the multitude.
Psalm 109:31	For he stands at the right hand of the poor, in order to save my soul from persecutors.

Psalm 128:3	Your wife is like an abundant vine on the sides of your house. Your sons are like young olive trees surrounding your table.
Psalm 128:4	Behold, so will the man be blessed who fears the Lord.
Psalm 128:5	May the Lord bless you from Zion, and may you see the good things of Jerusalem, all the days of your life.
Psalm 128:6	And may you see the sons of your sons. Peace be upon Israel.
Psalm 129:1	A Canticle in steps. They have often fought against me from my youth, let Israel now say:
Psalm 129:2	they have often fought against me from my youth, yet they could not prevail over me.
Psalm 129:3	The sinners have made fabrications behind my back. They have prolonged their iniquity.
Psalm 129:4	The just Lord will cut the necks of sinners.
Psalm 129:5	Let all those who hate Zion be confounded and turned backwards.
Psalm 129:6	Let them be like grass on the rooftops, which withers before it can be pulled up:
Psalm 129:7	with it, he who reaps does not fill his hand and he who gathers sheaves does not fill his bosom.
Psalm 129:8	And those who were passing by have not said to them: “The blessing of the Lord be upon you. We have blessed you in the name of the Lord.”
Psalm 130:1	A Canticle in steps. From the depths, I have cried out to you, O Lord.
Psalm 130:2	O Lord, hear my voice. Let your ears be attentive to the voice of my supplication.
Psalm 130:3	If you, O Lord, were to heed iniquities, who, O Lord, could persevere?
Psalm 130:4	For with you, there is forgiveness, and because of your law, I persevered with you, Lord. My soul has persevered in his word.
Psalm 130:5	My soul has hoped in the Lord.
Psalm 130:6	From the morning watch, even until night, let Israel hope in the Lord.
Psalm 130:7	For with the Lord there is mercy, and with him there is bountiful redemption.
Psalm 130:8	And he will redeem Israel from all his iniquities.
Psalm 131:1	A Canticle in steps: of David. O Lord, my heart has not been exalted, and my eyes have not been raised up. Neither have I walked in greatness, nor in wonders beyond me.
Psalm 131:2	When I was not humble in thought, then I lifted up my soul. Like one who has been weaned from his mother, so was I recompensed in my soul.
Psalm 131:3	Let Israel hope in the Lord, from this time forward and even forever.
Psalm 132:1	A Canticle in steps. O Lord, remember David and all his meekness,
Psalm 132:2	how he swore to the Lord, how he made a vow to the God of Jacob:
Psalm 132:3	I shall not enter into the tabernacle of my house, nor climb into the bed where I lie down;
Psalm 132:4	I shall not give sleep to my eyes, nor slumber to my eyelids
Psalm 132:5	and rest to my temples, until I find a place for the Lord, a tabernacle for the God of Jacob.
Psalm 132:6	Behold, we heard of it in Ephrathah. We discovered it in the fields of the forest.
Psalm 132:7	We will enter into his tabernacle. We will adore in the place where his feet stood.
Psalm 132:8	Rise up, O Lord, into your resting place. You and the ark of your sanctification.
Psalm 132:9	Let your priests be clothed with justice, and let your saints exult.
Psalm 132:10	For the sake of your servant David, do not turn away the face of your Christ.
Psalm 132:11	The Lord has sworn the truth to David, and he will not disappoint: I will set upon your throne from the fruit of your lineage.
Psalm 132:12	If your sons will keep my covenant and these, my testimonies, which I will teach to them, then their sons will sit upon your throne even forever.
Psalm 132:13	For the Lord has chosen Zion. He has chosen it as his dwelling place.
Psalm 132:14	This is my resting place, forever and ever. Here I will dwell, for I have chosen it.
Psalm 132:15	When blessing, I will bless her widow. I will satisfy her poor with bread.
Psalm 132:16	I will clothe her priests with salvation, and her saints will rejoice with great joy.
Psalm 132:17	There, I will produce a horn to David. There, I have prepared a lamp for my Christ.
Psalm 132:18	I will clothe his enemies with confusion. But my sanctification will flourish over him.
Psalm 133:1	A Canticle in steps: of David. Behold, how good and how pleasing it is for brothers to dwell in unity.
Psalm 133:2	It is like the ointment on the head that descended to the beard, the beard of Aaron, which descended to the hem of his garment.
Psalm 133:3	It is like the dew of Hermon, which descended from mount Zion. For in that place, the Lord has commanded a blessing, and life, even unto eternity.

Psalm 135:1	Alleluia. Praise the name of the Lord. You servants, praise the Lord.
Psalm 135:2	You who stand in the house of the Lord, in the courts of the house of our God:
Psalm 135:3	praise the Lord, for the Lord is good. Sing psalms to his name, for it is sweet.
Psalm 135:4	For the Lord has chosen Jacob for himself, Israel for his own possession.
Psalm 135:5	For I have known that the Lord is great, and our God is before all gods.
Psalm 135:6	All things whatsoever that he willed, the Lord did: in heaven, on earth, in the sea, and in all the deep places.
Psalm 135:7	He leads clouds from the ends of the earth. He has created lightnings in the rain. He has produced winds from his storehouses.
Psalm 135:8	He struck the first-born of Egypt, from man even to cattle.
Psalm 135:9	He sent signs and wonders into your midst, O Egypt: upon Pharaoh and upon all his servants.
Psalm 135:10	He has struck many nations, and he has slaughtered strong kings:
Psalm 135:11	Sihon, king of the Amorites, and Og, king of Bashan, and all the kingdoms of Canaan.
Psalm 135:12	And he gave their land as an inheritance, as an inheritance for his people Israel.
Psalm 135:13	Your name, O Lord, is in eternity. Your memorial, O Lord, is from generation to generation.
Psalm 135:14	For the Lord will judge his people, and he will be petitioned by his servants.
Psalm 135:15	The idols of the Gentiles are silver and gold, the works of the hands of men.
Psalm 135:16	They have a mouth, and do not speak. They have eyes, and do not see.
Psalm 135:17	They have ears, and do not hear. For neither is there any breath in their mouths.
Psalm 135:18	Let those who make them become like them, along with all who trust in them.
Psalm 135:19	Bless the Lord, O house of Israel. Bless the Lord, O house of Aaron.
Psalm 135:20	Bless the Lord, O house of Levi. You who fear the Lord, bless the Lord.
Psalm 135:21	The Lord is blessed from Zion, by those who dwell in Jerusalem.
Psalm 136:1	Alleluia. Confess to the Lord, for he is good: for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:2	Confess to the God of gods, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:3	Confess to the Lord of lords, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:4	He alone performs great miracles, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:5	He made the heavens with understanding, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:6	He established the earth above the waters, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:7	He made the great lights, for his mercy is eternal:
Psalm 136:8	the sun to rule the day, for his mercy is eternal:
Psalm 136:9	the moon and the stars to rule the night, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:10	He struck Egypt along with their first-born, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:11	He led Israel away from their midst, for his mercy is eternal:
Psalm 136:12	with a powerful hand and an outstretched arm, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:13	He divided the Red Sea into separate parts, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:14	And he led out Israel through the middle of it, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:15	And he shook off Pharaoh and his army in the Red Sea, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:16	He led his people through the desert, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:17	He has struck great kings, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:18	And he has slaughtered strong kings, for his mercy is eternal:
Psalm 136:19	Sihon, king of the Amorites, for his mercy is eternal:
Psalm 136:20	and Og, king of Bashan, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:21	And he granted their land as an inheritance, for his mercy is eternal:
Psalm 136:22	as an inheritance for his servant Israel, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:23	For he was mindful of us in our humiliation, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:24	And he redeemed us from our enemies, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:25	He gives food to all flesh, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 136:26	Confess to the God of heaven, for his mercy is eternal. Confess to the Lord of lords, for his mercy is eternal.
Psalm 137:1	A Psalm of David: to Jeremiah. Above the rivers of Babylon, there we sat and wept, while we remembered Zion.
Psalm 137:2	By the willow trees, in their midst, we hung up our instruments.
Psalm 137:3	For, in that place, those who led us into captivity questioned us about the words of the songs. And those who carried us away said: “Sing us a hymn from the songs of Zion.”
Psalm 137:4	How can we sing a song of the Lord in a foreign land?
Psalm 137:5	If I ever forget you, Jerusalem, let my right hand be forgotten.
Psalm 137:6	May my tongue adhere to my jaws, if I do not remember you, if I do not set Jerusalem first, as the beginning of my joy.
Psalm 137:7	O Lord, call to mind the sons of Edom, in the day of Jerusalem, who say: “Despoil it, despoil it, even to its foundation.”
Psalm 137:8	O daughter of Babylon, have pity. Blessed is he who will repay you with your payment, which you have paid to us.
Psalm 137:9	Blessed is he who will take hold of your little ones and dash them against the rock.
Psalm 138:1	Of David himself. O Lord, I will confess to you with my whole heart, for you have heard the words of my mouth. I will sing psalms to you in the sight of the Angels.
Psalm 138:2	I will adore before your holy temple, and I will confess your name: it is above your mercy and your truth. For you have magnified your holy name above all.
Psalm 138:3	On whatever day that I will call upon you: hear me. You will multiply virtue in my soul.
Psalm 138:4	May all the kings of the earth confess to you, O Lord. For they have heard all the words of your mouth.
Psalm 138:5	And let them sing in accordance with the ways of the Lord. For great is the glory of the Lord.
Psalm 138:6	For the Lord is exalted, and he looks with favor on the humble. But the lofty he knows from a distance.
Psalm 138:7	If I wander into the midst of tribulation, you will revive me. For you extended your hand against the wrath of my enemies. And your right hand has accomplished my salvation.
Psalm 138:8	The Lord will provide retribution on my behalf. O Lord, your mercy is forever. Do not disdain the works of your hands.
Psalm 139:1	Unto the end. A Psalm of David. O Lord, you have examined me, and you have known me.
Psalm 139:2	You have known my sitting down and my rising up again.
Psalm 139:3	You have understood my thoughts from afar. My path and my fate, you have investigated.
Psalm 139:4	And you have foreseen all my ways. For there is no word in my tongue.
Psalm 139:5	Behold, O Lord, you have known all things: the newest and the very old. You have formed me, and you have placed your hand over me.
Psalm 139:6	Your knowledge has become a wonder to me. It has been reinforced, and I am not able to prevail against it.
Psalm 139:7	Where will I go from your Spirit? And where will I flee from your face?
Psalm 139:8	If I ascend into heaven, you are there. If I descend into Hell, you are near.
Psalm 139:9	If I assume my feathers in early morning, and dwell in the utmost parts of the sea,
Psalm 139:10	even there, your hand will lead me forth, and your right hand will hold me.
Psalm 139:11	And I said: Perhaps darkness will overwhelm me, and the night will be my illumination, to my delight.
Psalm 139:12	But darkness will not be impenetrable to you, and night will illuminate like the day: for just as its darkness is, so also is its light.
Psalm 139:13	For you have possessed my temperament. You have supported me from the womb of my mother.
Psalm 139:14	I will confess to you, for you have been magnified terribly. Your works are miraculous, as my soul knows exceedingly well.
Psalm 139:15	My bone, which you have made in secret, has not been hidden from you, and my substance is in accord with the lower parts of the earth.
Psalm 139:16	Your eyes saw my imperfection, and all this shall be written in your book. Days will be formed, and no one shall be in them.
Psalm 139:17	But to me, O God, your friends have been greatly honored. Their first ruler has been exceedingly strengthened.
Psalm 139:18	I will number them, and they will be more numerous than the sand. I rose up, and I am still with you.
Psalm 139:19	O God, if only you would cut down sinners. You men of blood: depart from me.
Psalm 139:20	For you say in thought: They will accept your cities in vain.
Psalm 139:21	Have I not hated those who hated you, Lord, and wasted away because of your enemies?
Psalm 139:22	I have hated them with a perfect hatred, and they have become enemies to me.
Psalm 139:23	Examine me, O God, and know my heart. Question me, and know my paths.
Psalm 139:24	And see if there might be in me the way of iniquity, and lead me in the way of eternity.
Psalm 140:1	Unto the end. A Psalm of David. Rescue me, O Lord, from the evil man. Rescue me from the iniquitous leader.
Psalm 140:2	Those who have devised iniquities in their hearts: all day long they constructed conflicts.
Psalm 140:3	They have sharpened their tongues like a serpent. The venom of asps is under their lips.
Psalm 140:4	Preserve me, O Lord, from the hand of the sinner, and rescue me from men of iniquity. They have decided to supplant my steps.
Psalm 140:5	The arrogant have hidden a snare for me. And they have stretched out cords for a snare. They have placed a stumbling block for me near the road.
Psalm 140:6	I said to the Lord: You are my God. O Lord, heed the voice of my supplication.
Psalm 140:7	Lord, O Lord, the strength of my salvation: you have overshadowed my head in the day of war.
Psalm 140:8	O Lord, do not hand me over to the sinner by my desire. They have plotted against me. Do not abandon me, lest they should triumph.
Psalm 140:9	The head of those who encompass me, the labor of their lips, will overwhelm them.
Psalm 140:10	Burning coals will fall upon them. You will cast them down into the fire, into miseries that they will not be able to withstand.
Psalm 140:11	A talkative man will not be guided aright upon the earth. Evils will drag the unjust man unto utter ruin.
Psalm 140:12	I know that the Lord will accomplish justice for the needy and vindication for the poor.
Psalm 140:13	So then, truly, the just will confess your name, and the upright will dwell with your countenance.
Psalm 141:1	A Psalm of David. O Lord, I have cried out to you, hear me. Attend to my voice, when I cry out to you.
Psalm 141:2	Let my prayer be guided like incense in your sight: the lifting up of my hands, like the evening sacrifice.
Psalm 141:3	O Lord, station a guard over my mouth and a door enclosing my lips.
Psalm 141:4	Do not turn aside my heart to words of malice, to making excuses for sins, with men who work iniquity; and I will not communicate, even with the best of them.
Psalm 141:5	The just one will correct me with mercy, and he will rebuke me. But do not allow the oil of the sinner to fatten my head. For my prayer will still be toward their good will.
Psalm 141:6	Their judges have been engulfed, joined to the rocks. They will hear my words, which have prevailed,
Psalm 141:7	as when the lava of the earth has erupted above ground. Our bones have been scattered beside Hell.
Psalm 141:8	For Lord, O Lord, my eyes look to you. In you, I have hoped. Do not take away my soul.
Psalm 141:9	Protect me from the snare that they have set up for me and from the scandals of those who work iniquity.
Psalm 141:10	The sinners will fall into his net. I am alone, until I pass over.
Psalm 142:1	The understanding of David. A prayer, when he was in the cave. With my voice, I cried out to the Lord. With my voice, I made supplication to the Lord.
Psalm 142:2	In his sight, I pour out my prayer, and before him, I declare my tribulation.
Psalm 142:3	Though my spirit may become faint within me, even then, you have known my paths. Along this way, which I have been walking, they have hidden a snare for me.
Psalm 142:4	I considered toward the right, and I looked, but there was no one who would know me. Flight has perished before me, and there is no one who has concern for my soul.
Psalm 142:5	I cried out to you, O Lord. I said: You are my hope, my portion in the land of the living.
Psalm 142:6	Attend to my supplication. For I have been humbled exceedingly. Free me from my persecutors, for they have been fortified against me.

Psalm 143:1	A Psalm of David, when his son Absalom was pursuing him. O Lord, hear my prayer. Incline your ear to my supplication in your truth. Heed me according to your justice.
Psalm 143:2	And do not enter into judgment with your servant. For all the living will not be justified in your sight.
Psalm 143:3	For the enemy has pursued my soul. He has lowered my life to the earth. He has stationed me in darkness, like the dead of ages past.
Psalm 143:4	And my spirit has been in anguish over me. My heart within me has been disturbed.
Psalm 143:5	I have called to mind the days of antiquity. I have been meditating on all your works. I have meditated on the workings of your hands.
Psalm 143:6	I have extended my hands to you. My soul is like a land without water before you.
Psalm 143:7	O Lord, heed me quickly. My spirit has grown faint. Do not turn your face away from me, lest I become like those who descend into the pit.
Psalm 143:8	Make me hear your mercy in the morning. For I have hoped in you. Make known to me the way that I should walk. For I have lifted up my soul to you.
Psalm 143:9	O Lord, rescue me from my enemies. I have fled to you.
Psalm 143:10	Teach me to do your will. For you are my God. Your good Spirit will lead me into the righteous land.
Psalm 143:11	For the sake of your name, O Lord, you will revive me in your fairness. You will lead my soul out of tribulation.
Psalm 143:12	And you will scatter my enemies in your mercy. And you will destroy all those who afflict my soul. For I am your servant.

Psalm 144:2	My mercy and my refuge, my supporter and my deliverer, my protector and him in whom I have hoped: he subdues my people under me.
Psalm 144:3	O Lord, what is man that you have become known to him? Or the son of man that you consider him?
Psalm 144:4	Man has been made similar to vanity. His days pass by like a shadow.
Psalm 144:5	O Lord, incline your heavens and descend. Touch the mountains, and they will smoke.
Psalm 144:6	Send a flash of lightning, and you will scatter them. Shoot your arrows, and you will set them in disarray.

Psalm 144:8	Their mouth has been speaking vain things, and their right hand is the right hand of iniquity.

Psalm 144:10	He gives salvation to kings. He has redeemed your servant David from the malignant sword.
Psalm 144:11	Rescue me, and deliver me from the hand of the sons of foreigners. Their mouth has been speaking vain things, and their right hand is the right hand of iniquity.
Psalm 144:12	Their sons are like new plantings in their youth. Their daughters are dressed up: adorned all around like the idols of a temple.
Psalm 144:13	Their cupboards are full: overflowing from one thing into another. Their sheep bear young, brought forth in abundance.
Psalm 144:14	Their cattle are fat. There is no ruined wall or passage, nor anyone crying out in their streets.
Psalm 144:15	They have called the people that has these things: blessed. But blessed is the people whose God is the Lord.

Psalm 147:3	He heals the contrite of heart, and he binds up their sorrows.

Psalm 147:9	He gives their food to beasts of burden and to young ravens that call upon him.
Psalm 147:10	He will not have good will for the strength of the horse, nor will he be well pleased with the legs of a man.

Psalm 150:2	Praise him for his virtues. Praise him according to the multitude of his greatness.
Psalm 150:3	Praise him with the sound of the trumpet. Praise him with psaltery and stringed instrument.
Psalm 150:4	Praise him with timbrel and choir. Praise him with strings and organ.
Psalm 150:5	Praise him with sweet-sounding cymbals. Praise him with cymbals of jubilation.
Psalm 150:6	Let every spirit praise the Lord. Alleluia.
Proverbs 1:1	The parables of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel,
Proverbs 1:2	in order to know wisdom and discipline,
Proverbs 1:3	to understand words of prudence, and to accept the instruction of doctrine, justice and judgment, and equity,
Proverbs 1:4	so as to give discernment to little ones, knowledge and understanding to adolescents.
Proverbs 1:5	By listening, the wise shall become wiser and the intelligent shall possess governments.
Proverbs 1:6	He shall turn his soul to a parable and to its interpretation, to the words of the wise and their enigmas.
Proverbs 1:7	The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom. The foolish despise wisdom as well as doctrine.
Proverbs 1:8	Listen, my son, to the discipline of your father, and forsake not the law of your mother,
Proverbs 1:9	so that grace may be added to your head and a collar to your neck.
Proverbs 1:10	My son, if sinners should entice you, do not consent to them.
Proverbs 1:11	If they should say: “Come with us. We will lie in wait for blood. We will lay traps against the innocent, without cause.
Proverbs 1:12	Let us swallow him alive, like Hell, and whole, like one descending into the pit.
Proverbs 1:13	We will discover every precious substance. We will fill our houses with spoils.
Proverbs 1:14	Cast your lot with us. One purse will be for us all.”
Proverbs 1:15	My son, do not walk with them. Preclude your feet from their paths.
Proverbs 1:16	For their feet rush to evil, and they hurry to shed blood.
Proverbs 1:17	But a net is thrown in vain before the eyes of those who have wings.
Proverbs 1:18	Likewise, they lie in ambush against their own blood, and they undertake deceits against their own souls.
Proverbs 1:19	Thus, the ways of all those who are greedy seize the souls of those who possess.
Proverbs 1:20	Wisdom forewarns far and wide; she bestows her voice in the streets.
Proverbs 1:21	She cries out at the head of crowds; at the entrance of the gates of the city, she offers her words, saying:
Proverbs 1:22	“Little ones, how long will you choose to be childish, and how long will the foolish desire what is harmful to themselves, and how long will the imprudent hate knowledge?
Proverbs 1:23	Be converted by my correction. Lo, I will offer my spirit to you, and I will reveal my words to you.
Proverbs 1:24	For I called, and you refused. I extended my hand, and there was no one who watched.
Proverbs 1:25	You have despised all my counsels, and you have neglected my rebukes.
Proverbs 1:26	Similarly, I will ridicule you at your demise, and I will mock you, when that which you feared shall overcome you.
Proverbs 1:27	When sudden calamity rushes upon you, and your demise advances like a tempest, when tribulation and anguish overcome you,
Proverbs 1:28	then they will call to me, and I will not heed, they will arise in the morning, and not find me.
Proverbs 1:29	For they held hatred for discipline, and they would not accept the fear of the Lord;
Proverbs 1:30	they would not consent to my counsel, but they detracted from all of my corrections.
Proverbs 1:31	Therefore, they shall eat the fruit of their way, and they shall have their fill of their own counsels.
Proverbs 1:32	The loathing of the little ones shall destroy them, and the prosperity of the foolish shall perish them.
Proverbs 1:33	But whoever will listen to me shall rest without terror, and shall have full enjoyment of abundance, without fear of evils.”
Proverbs 2:1	My son, if you would accept my words, and conceal my commandments within you,
Proverbs 2:2	so that your ears may listen to wisdom, then bend your heart in order to know prudence.
Proverbs 2:3	For if you would call upon wisdom and bend your heart to prudence,
Proverbs 2:4	if you will seek her like money, and dig for her as if for treasure,
Proverbs 2:5	then you will understand the fear of the Lord, and you will discover the knowledge of God.
Proverbs 2:6	For the Lord bestows wisdom, and out of his mouth, prudence and knowledge.
Proverbs 2:7	He will preserve the salvation of the righteous, and he will protect those who walk in simplicity:
Proverbs 2:8	serving the paths of justice, and guarding the ways of sanctity.
Proverbs 2:9	Then you shall understand justice and judgment, and equity, and every good path.
Proverbs 2:10	If wisdom is to enter into your heart, and if knowledge is to become pleasing to your soul,
Proverbs 2:11	then counsel must guard you, and prudence must serve you,
Proverbs 2:12	so that you may be rescued from the evil way, and from the man who speaks perversities,
Proverbs 2:13	from those who leave the straight path to walk in dark ways,
Proverbs 2:14	who rejoice when they have done evil, and who exult in the most wicked things.
Proverbs 2:15	Their ways are perverse, and their steps are infamous.
Proverbs 2:16	So may you be rescued from the foreign woman, and from the outsider, who softens her speech,
Proverbs 2:17	and who leaves behind the Guide of her youth,
Proverbs 2:18	and who has forgotten the covenant of her God. For her household inclines toward death, and her paths toward Hell.
Proverbs 2:19	All those who enter to her will not return again, nor will they take hold of the paths of life.
Proverbs 2:20	So may you walk in the good way, and keep to the difficult paths of the just.
Proverbs 2:21	For those who are upright shall live upon the earth, and the simple shall continue upon it.
Proverbs 2:22	Yet truly, the impious shall perish from the earth, and those who act unjustly shall be taken away from it.
Proverbs 3:1	My son, do not forget my law, but let your heart guard my precepts.
Proverbs 3:2	For they shall set before you length of days, and years of life, and peace.
Proverbs 3:3	Let not mercy and truth abandon you: encircle them around your throat, and inscribe them on the tablets of your heart.
Proverbs 3:4	And so shall you discover grace and good discipline, in the sight of God and men.
Proverbs 3:5	Have confidence in the Lord with all your heart, and do not depend upon your own prudence.
Proverbs 3:6	In all your ways, consider him, and he himself will direct your steps.
Proverbs 3:7	Do not seem wise to yourself. Fear God, and withdraw from evil.
Proverbs 3:8	Certainly, it shall be health to your navel, and refreshment to your bones.
Proverbs 3:9	Honor the Lord with your substance, and give to him from the first of all your fruits,
Proverbs 3:10	and then your storehouses will be filled with abundance, and your presses shall overflow with wine.
Proverbs 3:11	My son, do not discard the discipline of the Lord, and do not fall away when you are corrected by him.
Proverbs 3:12	For whomever the Lord loves, he corrects, and just as a father does with a son, he wins him over.
Proverbs 3:13	Blessed is the man who finds wisdom and who advances to prudence.
Proverbs 3:14	Her acquisition is better than trading in silver, and her fruit is better than the first and purest gold.
Proverbs 3:15	She is more precious than all riches, and all that can be desired cannot prevail in comparison to her.
Proverbs 3:16	Length of days is at her right hand, and at her left hand is wealth and glory.
Proverbs 3:17	Her ways are beautiful ways, and all her paths are peaceful.
Proverbs 3:18	She is a tree of life to those who overtake her, and he who shall take hold of her is blessed.
Proverbs 3:19	The Lord founded the earth on wisdom. He secured the heavens with prudence.
Proverbs 3:20	By his wisdom, the abyss erupted and the clouds increased with dew.
Proverbs 3:21	My son, let not these things move away from your eyes. Preserve law as well as counsel.
Proverbs 3:22	And so shall there be life in your soul and grace in your voice.
Proverbs 3:23	Then you shall walk confidently in your way, and your feet will not stumble.
Proverbs 3:24	When you slumber, you shall not fear. When you rest, your sleep also will be sweet.
Proverbs 3:25	Do not fear unexpected terror, nor the power of the impious falling upon you.
Proverbs 3:26	For the Lord will be at your side, and he will guard your feet, so that you may not be seized.
Proverbs 3:27	Do not prevent him who is able from doing good. When you are able, do good yourself too.
Proverbs 3:28	Do not say to your friend: “Go away, and then return. Tomorrow I will give to you.” When you are able to do so, give in the present.
Proverbs 3:29	Do not undertake evil against your friend, even though he has trust in you.
Proverbs 3:30	Do not contend against a man without cause, even though he has done no evil to you.
Proverbs 3:31	Do not rival an unjust man, and do not imitate his ways.
Proverbs 3:32	For everyone who ridicules is an abomination to the Lord, and his communication is for the simple.
Proverbs 3:33	Destitution in the house of the impious is from the Lord. But the habitations of the just shall be blessed.
Proverbs 3:34	He will ridicule those who ridicule, but he will bestow grace upon the mild.
Proverbs 3:35	The wise will possess glory. The exaltation of the foolish is disgraceful.
Proverbs 4:1	Listen, sons, to the discipline of a father, and pay attention, so that you may know prudence.
Proverbs 4:2	I will bestow upon you a good gift. Do not relinquish my law.
Proverbs 4:3	For I, too, was the son of my father, tender and an only son in the sight of my mother.
Proverbs 4:4	And he taught me, and he also said: “Let your heart accept my words. Keep my precepts, and you shall live.
Proverbs 4:5	Obtain wisdom, obtain prudence. May you neither forget, nor turn away from, the words of my mouth.
Proverbs 4:6	Do not send her away, and she will guard you. Love her, and she will preserve you.
Proverbs 4:7	The beginning of wisdom is to obtain wisdom, and, with all that you possess, to acquire prudence.
Proverbs 4:8	Grasp her, and she will exalt you. You will be glorified by her, when you have embraced her.
Proverbs 4:9	She will bestow upon your head an increase in graces, and she will protect you with a noble crown.
Proverbs 4:10	Listen, my son, and accept my words, so that years of life may be multiplied for you.
Proverbs 4:11	I will demonstrate to you the way of wisdom. I will lead you along the paths of equity.
Proverbs 4:12	When you have entered by these, your steps will not be constrained, and when running, you will have no obstacle.
Proverbs 4:13	Take hold of discipline. Do not dismiss it. Guard it, for it is your life.
Proverbs 4:14	Do not delight in the paths of the impious, nor permit the way of evil-doers to please you.
Proverbs 4:15	Take flight from it. Do not pass close to it. Turn away and abandon it.
Proverbs 4:16	For they do not sleep, unless they have done evil. And their sleep is quickly taken away from them, unless they have overthrown.
Proverbs 4:17	They eat the bread of impiety, and they drink the wine of iniquity.
Proverbs 4:18	But the path of the just is like a shining light: it advances and increases, even to the day of completion.
Proverbs 4:19	The way of the impious is darkened. They do not know where they may fall.
Proverbs 4:20	My son, pay attention to my sermons, and incline your ear to my eloquent words.
Proverbs 4:21	Let them not recede from your eyes. Keep them in the midst of your heart.
Proverbs 4:22	For they are life to those who find them and health to all that is flesh.
Proverbs 4:23	Preserve your heart with all watchfulness, for life proceeds from this.
Proverbs 4:24	Remove from yourself a corrupt mouth, and let detracting lips be far from you.
Proverbs 4:25	Let your eyes look straight ahead, and let your eyelids precede your steps.
Proverbs 4:26	Direct the path of your feet, and all your ways shall be secure.
Proverbs 4:27	Turn aside, neither to the right, nor to the left; yet turn your foot away from evil. For the Lord knows the ways that are on the right, and truly, those that are on the left are perverse. But he himself will make your courses straight. Then your journey will advance in peace.
Proverbs 5:1	My son, pay attention to my wisdom, and incline your ear to my prudence,
Proverbs 5:2	so that you may guard your thinking, and so that your lips may preserve discipline. Do not pay attention to the deceit of a woman.
Proverbs 5:3	For the lips of a loose woman are like a dripping honeycomb, and her voice is smoother than oil.
Proverbs 5:4	But in the end, she is as bitter as wormwood, and as sharp as a two-edged sword.
Proverbs 5:5	Her feet descend into death, and her steps reach even to Hell.
Proverbs 5:6	They do not walk along the path of life; her steps are wandering and untraceable.
Proverbs 5:7	Therefore, my son, listen to me now, and do not withdraw from the words of my mouth.
Proverbs 5:8	Make your way at a distance from her, and do not approach the doors of her house.
Proverbs 5:9	Do not give your honor to foreigners, and your years to the cruel.
Proverbs 5:10	Otherwise, outsiders may be filled with your strength, and your labors may be in a foreign house,
Proverbs 5:11	and you may mourn in the end, when you will have consumed your flesh and your body. And so you may say:
Proverbs 5:12	“Why have I detested discipline, and why has my heart not been quieted by correction?
Proverbs 5:13	And why have I not listened to the voice of those who guided me? And why has my ear not inclined to my teachers?
Proverbs 5:14	I have almost been with all evil in the midst of the church and of the assembly.”
Proverbs 5:15	Drink water from your own cistern and from the springs of your own well.
Proverbs 5:16	Let your fountains be diverted far and wide, and divide your waters in the streets.
Proverbs 5:17	Hold them for yourself alone, and do not let strangers be partakers with you.
Proverbs 5:18	Let your spring be blessed, and rejoice with the wife of your youth:
Proverbs 5:19	a beloved doe and most pleasing fawn. Let her breasts inebriate you at all times. Be delighted continually by her love.
Proverbs 5:20	Why are you seduced, my son, by a strange woman, and why are you kept warm by the bosom of another?
Proverbs 5:21	The Lord beholds the ways of man, and he considers all his steps.
Proverbs 5:22	His own iniquities take hold of the impious, and he is bound by the cords of his own sins.
Proverbs 5:23	He shall die, for he has not held to discipline. And by the multitude of his foolishness, he shall be deceived.
Proverbs 6:1	My son, if you have taken a pledge on behalf of your friend, then you have bound your hand to an outsider,
Proverbs 6:2	then you are ensnared by the words of your own mouth, and taken captive by your own words.
Proverbs 6:3	Therefore, my son, do what I say, and free yourself, for you have fallen into the hand of your neighbor. Run, hurry, awaken your friend.
Proverbs 6:4	Do not grant sleep to your eyes, nor let your eyelids slumber.
Proverbs 6:5	Rescue yourself like a gazelle from the hand, and like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
Proverbs 6:6	Go to the ant, you lazy one, and consider her ways, and so learn wisdom.
Proverbs 6:7	For though she has no ruler, nor instructor, nor leader,
Proverbs 6:8	she provides meals for herself in the summer, and she gathers at the harvest what she may eat.
Proverbs 6:9	How long will you slumber, you lazy one? When will you rise up from your sleep?
Proverbs 6:10	You will sleep a little, you will slumber a little, you will fold your hands a little to sleep,
Proverbs 6:11	and then destitution will meet with you, like a traveler, and poverty, like an armed man. Yet truly, if you would be diligent, then your harvest will arrive like a fountain, and destitution will flee far from you.
Proverbs 6:12	An apostate man, a harmful man, walks with a perverse mouth;
Proverbs 6:13	he winks with the eyes, touches with the foot, speaks with the finger.
Proverbs 6:14	With a depraved heart he devises evil, and at all times he sows conflict.
Proverbs 6:15	To this one, his perdition will arrive promptly, and he shall be crushed suddenly: he will no longer have any remedy.
Proverbs 6:16	Six things there are that the Lord hates, and the seventh, his soul detests:
Proverbs 6:17	haughty eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,
Proverbs 6:18	a heart that devises the most wicked thoughts, feet running swiftly unto evil,
Proverbs 6:19	a deceitful witness bringing forth lies, and he who sows discord among brothers.
Proverbs 6:20	My son, preserve the precepts of your father, and do not dismiss the law of your mother.
Proverbs 6:21	Bind them to your heart unceasingly, and encircle them around your throat.
Proverbs 6:22	When you walk, let them keep step with you. When you sleep, let them guard you. And when you keep watch, speak with them.
Proverbs 6:23	For commandment is a lamp, and law is a light, and the reproofs of discipline are the way of life.
Proverbs 6:24	So may they guard you from an evil woman, and from the flattering tongue of the outsider.
Proverbs 6:25	Let not your heart desire her beauty; do not be captivated by her winks.
Proverbs 6:26	For the price of a prostitute is only one loaf. Yet the woman seizes the precious soul of a man.
Proverbs 6:27	Would a man be able to conceal fire in his bosom, so that his garments would not burn?
Proverbs 6:28	Or could he walk over burning coals, so that his feet would not be burned?
Proverbs 6:29	So also, he who enters to the wife of his neighbor shall not be clean when he touches her.
Proverbs 6:30	Not so great is the fault when someone has stolen. For he steals so as to satisfy a hungry soul.
Proverbs 6:31	Also, if he is apprehended, he shall repay sevenfold and hand over all the substance of his house.
Proverbs 6:32	But whoever is an adulterer, because of the emptiness of his heart, will destroy his own soul.
Proverbs 6:33	He gathers shame and dishonor to himself, and his disgrace will not be wiped away.
Proverbs 6:34	For the jealousy and fury of the husband will not spare him on the day of vindication,
Proverbs 6:35	nor will he agree to the pleadings of anyone, nor will he accept, as repayment, a multitude of gifts.
Proverbs 7:1	My son, guard my words and conceal my precepts within you.
Proverbs 7:2	Son, preserve my commandments, and you shall live. And keep my law as the pupil of your eye.
Proverbs 7:3	Bind it with your fingers; write it on the tablets of your heart.
Proverbs 7:4	Say to wisdom, “You are my sister,” and call prudence your friend.
Proverbs 7:5	So may she guard you from the woman who is an outsider, and from the stranger who sweetens her words.
Proverbs 7:6	For I gaze from the window of my house, through the lattice,
Proverbs 7:7	and I see little ones. I consider a frenzied youth,
Proverbs 7:8	who crosses the street at the corner and close to the way of that house.
Proverbs 7:9	He steps into shadows, as day becomes evening, into the darkness and gloom of the night.
Proverbs 7:10	And behold, a woman meets him, dressed like a harlot, prepared to captivate souls: chattering and rambling,
Proverbs 7:11	unwilling to bear silence, unable to keep her feet at home,
Proverbs 7:12	now outside, now in the streets, now lying in ambush near the corners.
Proverbs 7:13	And overtaking the youth, she kisses him, and with a provocative face, she flatters him, saying:
Proverbs 7:14	“I vowed sacrifices for well-being. Today I have repaid my vows.
Proverbs 7:15	Because of this, I have gone out to meet you, desiring to see you, and I have found you.
Proverbs 7:16	I have woven my bed with cords. I have strewn it with embroidered tapestries from Egypt.
Proverbs 7:17	I have sprinkled my bed with myrrh, aloe, and cinnamon.
Proverbs 7:18	Come, let us be inebriated in abundance, and let us delight in the embraces of desire, until the day begins to dawn.
Proverbs 7:19	For my husband is not in his house. He has gone away on a very long journey.
Proverbs 7:20	He took with him a bag of money. He will return to his house on the day of the full moon.”
Proverbs 7:21	She enmeshed him with many words, and she drew him forward with the flattery of her lips.
Proverbs 7:22	Immediately, he follows her, like an ox being led to the sacrifice, and like a lamb acting lasciviously, and not knowing that he is being drawn foolishly into chains,
Proverbs 7:23	until the arrow pierces his liver. It is just as if a bird were to hurry into the snare. And he does not know that his actions endanger his own soul.
Proverbs 7:24	Therefore, my son, hear me now, and attend to the words of my mouth.
Proverbs 7:25	Do not let your mind be pulled into her ways. And do not be deceived by her paths.
Proverbs 7:26	For she has tossed aside many wounded, and some of those who were very strong have been slain by her.
Proverbs 7:27	Her household is the way to Hell, reaching even to the inner places of death.
Proverbs 8:1	Does not wisdom call out, and prudence bestow her voice?
Proverbs 8:2	At the summits and the tops of exalted places, standing above the ways, in the midst of the paths,
Proverbs 8:3	beside the gates of the city, at the very doors, she speaks, saying:
Proverbs 8:4	“O men, to you I call out, and my voice is to the sons of men.
Proverbs 8:5	O little ones, understand discernment. And you who are unwise, turn your souls.
Proverbs 8:6	Listen, for I will speak about great things, and my lips will be opened, so as to foretell what is right.
Proverbs 8:7	My throat shall practice truth, and my lips shall detest the impious.
Proverbs 8:8	All my words are just. There is no depravity in them, and no perversity.
Proverbs 8:9	They are upright to those who understand, and equitable to those who discover knowledge.
Proverbs 8:10	Accept my discipline, and not money. Choose the doctrine that is greater than gold.
Proverbs 8:11	For wisdom is better than all that is most precious, and everything that is desirable cannot compare to her.
Proverbs 8:12	I, wisdom, dwell in counsel, and I am inside learned thoughts.
Proverbs 8:13	The fear of the Lord hates evil. I detest arrogance, and pride, and every wicked way, and a mouth with a double tongue.
Proverbs 8:14	Counsel is mine, and equity. Prudence is mine. Strength is mine.
Proverbs 8:15	Through me, kings reign and legislators decree just conditions.
Proverbs 8:16	Through me, princes rule and the powerful decree justice.
Proverbs 8:17	I love those who love me. And those who stand watch for me until morning shall discover me.
Proverbs 8:18	With me, are wealth and glory, superb riches and justice.
Proverbs 8:19	For my fruit is better than gold and precious stones, and my progeny better than choice silver.
Proverbs 8:20	I walk in the way of justice, in the midst of the paths of judgment,
Proverbs 8:21	so that I may enrich those who love me, and thus complete their treasures.
Proverbs 8:22	The Lord possessed me in the beginning of his ways, before he made anything, from the beginning.
Proverbs 8:23	I was ordained from eternity, and out of antiquity, before the earth was formed.
Proverbs 8:24	The abyss did not yet exist, and I was already conceived; neither had the fountains of waters yet erupted.
Proverbs 8:25	The mountains, with their great mass, had not yet been established. Before the hills, I was brought forth.
Proverbs 8:26	Still he had not made the earth, and the rivers, and the poles of the globe of the earth.
Proverbs 8:27	I was already present: when he prepared the heavens; when, with a certain law and a circuit, he fortified the abyss;
Proverbs 8:28	when he made firm the sky above, and set free the fountains of waters;
Proverbs 8:29	when he encompassed the sea within its limits, and laid down a law for the waters, lest they transgress their limits; when he weighed the foundations of the earth.
Proverbs 8:30	I was with him in composing all things. And I was delighted, throughout every day, by playing in his sight at all times,
Proverbs 8:31	playing in globe of the earth. And my delight was to be with the sons of men.
Proverbs 8:32	Therefore, sons, hear me now. Blessed are those who preserve my ways.
Proverbs 8:33	Listen to discipline, and become wise, and do not be willing to cast it aside.
Proverbs 8:34	Blessed is the man who listens to me, and who stands watch at my gates everyday, and who observes at the posts of my doors.
Proverbs 8:35	He who finds me, finds life, and he will draw salvation from the Lord.
Proverbs 8:36	But he who sins against me will wound his own soul. All who hate me love death.”
Proverbs 9:1	Wisdom has built a house for herself. She has hewn seven columns.
Proverbs 9:2	She has immolated her victims. She has mixed her wine and set forth her table.
Proverbs 9:3	She has sent her maids to call out to the tower and to the fortified walls of the city,
Proverbs 9:4	“If anyone is little, let him come to me.” And to the unwise, she has said:
Proverbs 9:5	“Approach. Eat my bread, and drink the wine that I have mixed for you.
Proverbs 9:6	Leave behind childishness. And live and walk by the ways of prudence.”
Proverbs 9:7	Whoever teaches a mocker causes injury to himself. And whoever argues with the impious produces a blemish on himself.
Proverbs 9:8	Do not be willing to argue with a mocker, lest he hate you. Dispute with the wise, and he will love you.
Proverbs 9:9	Present an opportunity to the wise, and wisdom shall be added to him. Teach the just, and he will hurry to receive it.
Proverbs 9:10	The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and knowledge of holiness is prudence.
Proverbs 9:11	For by me, your days will be multiplied and years of life will be added to you.
Proverbs 9:12	If you would be wise, you will be so for yourself. But if you would be one who ridicules, you alone shall carry the evil.
Proverbs 9:13	A foolish and loud woman, who is full of enticements and who knows nothing at all,
Proverbs 9:14	sat at the entrance of her house on a seat, in a high place of the city,
Proverbs 9:15	so as to call to those who were passing by the way and continuing on their journey:
Proverbs 9:16	“Whoever is little, let him turn aside to me.” And to the frenzied, she said,
Proverbs 9:17	“Stolen waters are more soothing, and secret bread is more pleasant.”
Proverbs 9:18	And he did not know that giants are there, and that her companions are in the depths of Hell.
Proverbs 10:1	A wise son gladdens the father. Yet truly, a foolish son is the grief of his mother.
Proverbs 10:2	Treasures of impiety will profit nothing. Truly, justice shall liberate from death.
Proverbs 10:3	The Lord will not afflict with famine the soul of the just, and he will overthrow the treacheries of the impious.
Proverbs 10:4	The neglectful hand has wrought destitution. But the hand of the steadfast prepares riches. He who advances by lies, this one feeds on the wind. For he is the same as one who runs after flying birds.
Proverbs 10:5	He who gathers the harvest is a wise son. But he who snores in warm weather is a son of confusion.
Proverbs 10:6	The blessing of the Lord is on the head of the just. But iniquity covers the mouth of the impious.
Proverbs 10:7	The remembrance of the just is with praises. And the name of the impious shall decay.
Proverbs 10:8	The wise of heart accept precepts. The foolish are cut down by the lips.
Proverbs 10:9	He who walks in simplicity walks in confidence. But he who corrupts his ways shall be discovered.
Proverbs 10:10	He who winks with the eye gives sorrow. And the foolish in lips shall be beaten.
Proverbs 10:11	The mouth of the just is a vein of life. And the mouth of the impious covers iniquity.
Proverbs 10:12	Hatred rises up from disputes. And charity covers all offenses.
Proverbs 10:13	In the lips of the wise, wisdom is discovered. And a rod is for the back of one who lacks heart.
Proverbs 10:14	The wise store away knowledge. But the mouth of the foolish is a neighbor to confusion.

Proverbs 10:19	In a multitude of speaking, sin will not be lacking. But whoever tempers his lips is most prudent.
Proverbs 10:20	The tongue of the just is choice silver. But the heart of the impious is exchanged for nothing.

Proverbs 10:22	The blessing of the Lord causes riches. Affliction will not be a companion to them.

Proverbs 10:24	What the impious fear will overwhelm them. The just shall be given their desire.
Proverbs 10:25	Like a passing tempest, so the impious one will be no more. But the just one is like an everlasting foundation.
Proverbs 10:26	Like vinegar to the teeth, and smoke to the eyes, so is a lazy one to those who sent him.
Proverbs 10:27	The fear of the Lord adds days. And the years of the impious will be shortened.
Proverbs 10:28	The expectation of the just is rejoicing. But the hope of the impious will perish.

Proverbs 10:30	The just in eternity shall not be moved. But the impious will not live upon the earth.

Proverbs 11:1	A deceitful scale is an abomination with the Lord, and a fair weighing is his will.

Proverbs 11:25	The soul that blesses shall be made fat. And whoever inebriates will likewise be inebriated himself.
Proverbs 11:26	Whoever hides away grain shall be cursed among the people. But a blessing is upon the head of those who sell it.
Proverbs 11:27	He does well to rise early, who seeks what is good. But whoever is a seeker of evils shall be oppressed by them.
Proverbs 11:28	Whoever trusts in his riches will fall. But the just shall spring up like a green leaf.

Proverbs 27:19	In the manner of faces looking into shining water, so are the hearts of men made manifest to the prudent.
Proverbs 27:20	Hell and perdition are never filled; similarly the eyes of men are insatiable.
Proverbs 27:21	In the manner of silver being tested in the refinery, and gold in the furnace, so also is a man tested by the mouth of one who praises. The heart of the iniquitous inquires after evils, but the heart of the righteous inquires after knowledge.
Proverbs 27:22	Even if you were to crush the foolish with a mortar, as when a pestle strikes over pearled barley, his foolishness would not be taken from him.
Proverbs 27:23	Be diligent to know the countenance of your cattle, and consider your own flocks,
Proverbs 27:24	for you will not always hold this power. But a crown shall be awarded from generation to generation.
Proverbs 27:25	The meadows are open, and the green plants have appeared, and the hay has been collected from the mountains.
Proverbs 27:26	Lambs are for your clothing, and goats are for the price of a field.
Proverbs 27:27	Let the milk of goats be sufficient for your food, and for the necessities of your household, and for the provisions of your handmaids.
Proverbs 28:1	The impious flees, though no one pursues. But the just, like a confident lion, shall be without dread.
Proverbs 28:2	Because of the sins of the land, it has many princes. And because of the wisdom of a man, and the knowledge of those things that are said, the life of the leader shall be prolonged.
Proverbs 28:3	A poor man slandering the poor is like a violent rainstorm in advance of a famine.
Proverbs 28:4	Those who abandon the law praise the impious. Those who guard it are inflamed against him.
Proverbs 28:5	Evil men do not intend judgment. But those who inquire after the Lord turn their souls toward all things.
Proverbs 28:6	Better is the pauper walking in his simplicity, than the rich walking in ways of depravity.
Proverbs 28:7	Whoever keeps the law is a wise son. But whoever feeds gluttons brings shame to his father.
Proverbs 28:8	Whoever piles up riches by usury and profit gathers them for him who will give freely to the poor.
Proverbs 28:9	Whoever turns away his ears from listening to the law: his prayer will be detestable.
Proverbs 28:10	Whoever deceives the just in a malicious way will fall into his own perdition. And the simple shall possess his goods.
Proverbs 28:11	The rich one seems wise to himself. But the poor one, being prudent, shall evaluate him.
Proverbs 28:12	In the exultation of the just, there is great glory. When the impious reign, men are brought to ruin.
Proverbs 28:13	Whoever hides his crimes will not be guided. But whoever will have confessed and abandoned them shall overtake mercy.
Proverbs 28:14	Blessed is the man who is ever fearful. Yet truly, whoever is hardened in mind will fall into evil.
Proverbs 28:15	An impious leader over a poor people is like a roaring lion and a hungry bear.
Proverbs 28:16	A leader destitute of prudence will oppress many through false accusations. But whoever hates avarice shall prolong his days.
Proverbs 28:17	A man who slanders the blood of a life, even if he flees to the pit, no one will tolerate him.
Proverbs 28:18	Whoever walks simply shall be saved. Whoever is perverse in his steps will fall all at once.
Proverbs 28:19	Whoever works his land shall be satisfied with bread. But whoever pursues leisure will be filled with need.
Proverbs 28:20	A faithful man shall be greatly praised. But whoever rushes to become rich will not be innocent.
Proverbs 28:21	Whoever shows favoritism in judgment does not do well; even if it is for a morsel of bread, he forsakes the truth.
Proverbs 28:22	A man who hurries to become rich, and who envies others, does not know that destitution will overwhelm him.
Proverbs 28:23	Whoever corrects a man, afterward he shall find favor with him, more so than he who deceives him with a flattering tongue.
Proverbs 28:24	Whoever takes away anything from his father or mother, and who says, “This is not a sin,” is the associate of a murderer.
Proverbs 28:25	Whoever boasts and enlarges himself stirs up conflicts. Yet truly, whoever trusts in the Lord will be healed.
Proverbs 28:26	Whoever trusts in his own heart is a fool. But whoever treads wisely, the same shall be saved.
Proverbs 28:27	Whoever gives to the poor shall not be in need. Whoever despises his petition will suffer scarcity.
Proverbs 28:28	When the impious rise up, men will hide themselves. When they perish, the just shall be multiplied.
Proverbs 29:1	The man who, with a stiff neck, treats the one who corrects him with contempt will be suddenly overwhelmed to his own destruction, and reason shall not follow him.
Proverbs 29:2	When just men are multiplied, the common people shall rejoice. When the impious take up the leadership, the people shall mourn.
Proverbs 29:3	The man who loves wisdom rejoices his father. But whoever nurtures promiscuous women will lose his substance.
Proverbs 29:4	A just king guides the land. A man of avarice will destroy it.
Proverbs 29:5	A man who speaks to his friend with flattering and feigned words spreads a net for his own feet.
Proverbs 29:6	A snare will entangle the iniquitous when he sins. And the just shall praise and be glad.
Proverbs 29:7	The just knows the case of the poor. The impious is ignorant of knowledge.
Proverbs 29:8	Pestilent men squander a city. Yet truly, the wise avert fury.
Proverbs 29:9	A wise man, if he were to contend with the foolish, whether in anger or in laughter, would find no rest.
Proverbs 29:10	Bloodthirsty men hate the simple one; but the just seek out his soul.
Proverbs 29:11	A foolish one offers everything on his mind. A wise one reserves and defers until later.
Proverbs 29:12	A leader who freely listens to lying words has only impious servants.
Proverbs 29:13	The pauper and the creditor have met one another. The Lord is the illuminator of them both.
Proverbs 29:14	The king who judges the poor in truth, his throne shall be secured in eternity.
Proverbs 29:15	The rod and its correction distribute wisdom. But the child who is left to his own will brings shame to his mother.
Proverbs 29:16	When the impious are multiplied, crimes will be multiplied. But the just shall see their ruin.
Proverbs 29:17	Teach your son, and he will refresh you, and he will give delight to your soul.
Proverbs 29:18	When prophecy fails, the people will be scattered. Yet truly, whoever guards the law is blessed.
Proverbs 29:19	A servant cannot be taught by words, because he understands what you say, but he disdains to respond.
Proverbs 29:20	Have you seen a man rushing to speak? Foolishness has more hope than his correction.
Proverbs 29:21	Whoever nurtures his servant delicately from childhood, afterwards will find him defiant.
Proverbs 29:22	A short-tempered man provokes quarrels. And whoever is easily angered is more likely to sin.
Proverbs 29:23	Humiliation follows the arrogant. And glory shall uphold the humble in spirit.
Proverbs 29:24	Whoever participates with a thief hates his own soul; for he listens to his oath and does not denounce him.
Proverbs 29:25	Whoever fears man will quickly fall. Whoever hopes in the Lord shall be lifted up.
Proverbs 29:26	Many demand the face of the leader. But the judgment of each one proceeds from the Lord.
Proverbs 29:27	The just abhor an impious man. And the impious abhor those who are on the right way. By keeping the word, the son shall be free from perdition.
Proverbs 30:1	The words of the Gatherer, the son of the Vomiter. The vision that the man spoke. God is with him, and he, being strengthened by God and abiding with him, said:
Proverbs 30:2	“I am the most foolish among men, and the wisdom of men is not with me.
Proverbs 30:3	I have not learned wisdom, and I have not known the knowledge of sanctity.
Proverbs 30:4	Who has ascended to heaven and also descended? Who has grasped the wind in his hands? Who has tied the waters together, as with a garment? Who has raised all the limits of the earth? What is his name, and what is the name of his son, if you know?
Proverbs 30:5	Every word of God is fire-tested. He is a bronze shield to those who hope in him.
Proverbs 30:6	Do not add anything to his words, lest you be reproved and be discovered to be a liar.
Proverbs 30:7	Two things I have asked of you; do not deny them to me before I die.
Proverbs 30:8	Remove, far from me, vanity and lying words. Give me neither begging, nor wealth. Apportion to me only the necessities of my life,
Proverbs 30:9	lest perhaps, being filled, I might be enticed into denial, and say: ‘Who is the Lord?’ Or, being compelled by destitution, I might steal, and then perjure myself in the name of my God.
Proverbs 30:10	Do not accuse a servant to his lord, lest he curse you, and you fall.
Proverbs 30:11	There is a generation which curses their father, and which does not bless their mother.
Proverbs 30:12	There is a generation which seems pure to themselves, and yet they are not even washed from their filthiness.
Proverbs 30:13	There is a generation, whose eyes have been elevated, and their eyelids are lifted on high.
Proverbs 30:14	There is a generation which has swords in place of teeth, and which commands their molars to devour the indigent from the earth and the poor from among men.
Proverbs 30:15	The leech has two daughters, who say, ‘Bring, bring.’ Three things are insatiable, and a fourth never says ‘Enough’:
Proverbs 30:16	Hell, and the mouth of the womb, and a land that is not filled with water. And truly, fire never says, ‘Enough.’
Proverbs 30:17	The eye of one who mocks his father and who despises the childbearing of his mother, let the ravens of the torrent tear it out, and let the sons of the eagles consume it.
Proverbs 30:18	Three things are difficult for me, and about a fourth, I am nearly ignorant:
Proverbs 30:19	the way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a serpent on a rock, the way of a ship in the middle of the sea, and the way of a man in adolescence.
Proverbs 30:20	Such is the way also of an adulterous woman, who eats, and wiping her mouth, says: “I have done no evil.”
Proverbs 30:21	By three things, the earth is moved, and a fourth it is not able to sustain:
Proverbs 30:22	by a slave when he reigns, by the foolish when he has been filled with food,
Proverbs 30:23	by a hateful woman when she has been taken in matrimony, and by a handmaid when she has been heir to her mistress.
Proverbs 30:24	Four things are least upon the earth, and they are wiser than the wise:
Proverbs 30:25	the ants, an infirm people who provide food for themselves at the harvest,
Proverbs 30:26	the rabbit, a sickened people who make their bed upon the rock.
Proverbs 30:27	The locust has no king, but they all depart by their troops.
Proverbs 30:28	The lizard supports itself on hands and dwells in the buildings of kings.
Proverbs 30:29	There are three things that advance well, and a fourth that marches happily on:
Proverbs 30:30	a lion, the strongest of beasts, who fears nothing that he meets,
Proverbs 30:31	a rooster prepared at the loins, likewise a ram, and a king, whom none can resist.
Proverbs 30:32	There is one who has appeared foolish, after he was lifted up on high; for if he had understood, he would have placed his hand over his mouth.
Proverbs 30:33	But whoever strongly squeezes the udder to bring out the milk, presses out butter. And whoever violently blows his nose, brings out blood. And whoever provokes wrath, brings forth discord.”
Proverbs 31:1	The words of king Lamuel. The vision by which his mother instructed him:
Proverbs 31:2	“What, O my beloved? What, O beloved of my womb? What, O beloved of my vows?
Proverbs 31:3	Do not give your substance to women, or your riches to overthrow kings.
Proverbs 31:4	Not to kings, O Lamuel, not to kings give wine. For there are no secrets where drunkenness reigns.
Proverbs 31:5	And perhaps they may drink and forget judgments, and alter the case of the sons of the poor.
Proverbs 31:6	Give strong drink to the grieving, and wine to those who are bitter in soul.
Proverbs 31:7	Let them drink, and forget their needs, and remember their sorrow no more.
Proverbs 31:8	Open your mouth for the mute and for all the cases of the sons who are passing through.
Proverbs 31:9	Open your mouth, declare what is just, and do justice to the indigent and the poor.
Proverbs 31:10	Who shall find a strong woman? Far away, and from the furthest parts, is her price.
Proverbs 31:11	The heart of her husband confides in her, and he will not be deprived of spoils.
Proverbs 31:12	She will repay him with good, and not evil, all the days of her life.
Proverbs 31:13	She has sought wool and flax, and she has worked these by the counsel of her hands.
Proverbs 31:14	She has become like a merchant’s ship, bringing her bread from far away.
Proverbs 31:15	And she has risen in the night, and given a prey to her household, and provisions to her maids.
Proverbs 31:16	She has considered a field and bought it. From the fruit of her own hands, she has planted a vineyard.
Proverbs 31:17	She has wrapped her waist with fortitude, and she has strengthened her arm.
Proverbs 31:18	She has tasted and seen that her tasks are good; her lamp shall not be extinguished at night.
Proverbs 31:19	She has put her hand to strong things, and her fingers have taken hold of the spindle.
Proverbs 31:20	She has opened her hand to the needy, and she has extended her hands to the poor.
Proverbs 31:21	She shall not fear, in the cold of snow, for her household. For all those of her household have been clothed two-fold.
Proverbs 31:22	She has made embroidered clothing for herself. Fine linen and purple is her garment.
Proverbs 31:23	Her husband is noble at the gates, when he sits among the senators of the land.
Proverbs 31:24	She has made finely woven cloth and sold it, and she has delivered a waistband to the Canaanite.
Proverbs 31:25	Strength and elegance are her clothing, and she will laugh in the final days.
Proverbs 31:26	She has opened her mouth to wisdom, and the law of clemency is on her tongue.
Proverbs 31:27	She has considered the paths of her household, and she has not eaten her bread in idleness.
Proverbs 31:28	Her sons rose up and predicted great happiness; her husband rose up and praised her.
Proverbs 31:29	Many daughters have gathered together riches; you have surpassed them all.
Proverbs 31:30	Charm is false, and beauty is vain. The woman who fears the Lord, the same shall be praised.
Proverbs 31:31	Give to her from the fruit of her own hands. And let her works praise her at the gates.
Ecclesiastes 1:1	The words of Ecclesiastes, the son of David, the king of Jerusalem.
Ecclesiastes 1:2	Ecclesiastes said: Vanity of vanities! Vanity of vanities, and all is vanity!
Ecclesiastes 1:3	What more does a man have from all his labor, as he labors under the sun?
Ecclesiastes 1:4	A generation passes away, and a generation arrives. But the earth stands forever.
Ecclesiastes 1:5	The sun rises and sets; it returns to its place, and from there, being born again,
Ecclesiastes 1:6	it circles through the south, and arcs toward the north. The spirit continues on, illuminating everything in its circuit, and turning again in its cycle.
Ecclesiastes 1:7	All rivers enter into the sea, and the sea does not overflow. To the place from which the rivers go out, they return, so that they may flow again.
Ecclesiastes 1:8	Such things are difficult; man is not able to explain them with words. The eye is not satisfied by seeing, nor is the ear fulfilled by hearing.
Ecclesiastes 1:9	What is it that has existed? The same shall exist in the future. What is it that has been done? The same shall continue to be done.
Ecclesiastes 1:10	There is nothing new under the sun. Neither is anyone able to say: “Behold, this is new!” For it has already been brought forth in the ages that were before us.
Ecclesiastes 1:11	There is no remembrance of the former things. Indeed, neither shall there be any record of past things in the future, for those who will exist at the very end.
Ecclesiastes 1:12	I, Ecclesiastes, was king of Israel at Jerusalem.
Ecclesiastes 1:13	And I was determined in my mind to seek and to investigate wisely, concerning all that is done under the sun. God has given this very difficult task to the sons of men, so that they may be occupied by it.
Ecclesiastes 1:14	I have seen all that is done under the sun, and behold: all is emptiness and an affliction of the spirit.
Ecclesiastes 1:15	The perverse are unwilling to be corrected, and the number of the foolish is boundless.
Ecclesiastes 1:16	I have spoken in my heart, saying: “Behold, I have achieved greatness, and I have surpassed all the wise who were before me in Jerusalem.” And my mind has contemplated many things wisely, and I have learned.
Ecclesiastes 1:17	And I have dedicated my heart, so that I may know prudence and doctrine, and also error and foolishness. Yet I recognize that, in these things also, there is hardship, and affliction of the spirit.
Ecclesiastes 1:18	Because of this, with much wisdom there is also much anger. And whoever adds knowledge, also adds hardship.
Ecclesiastes 2:1	I said in my heart: “I will go forth and overflow with delights, and I will enjoy good things.” And I saw that this, too, is emptiness.
Ecclesiastes 2:2	Laughter, I considered an error. And to rejoicing, I said: “Why are you being deceived, to no purpose?”
Ecclesiastes 2:3	I decided in my heart to withdraw my flesh from wine, so that I might bring my mind to wisdom, and turn away from foolishness, until I see what is useful for the sons of men, and what they ought to do under the sun, during the number of the days of their life.
Ecclesiastes 2:4	I magnified my works. I built houses for myself, and I planted vineyards.
Ecclesiastes 2:5	I made gardens and orchards. And I planted them with trees of every kind.
Ecclesiastes 2:6	And I dug out fishponds of water, so that I might irrigate the forest of growing trees.
Ecclesiastes 2:7	I obtained men and women servants, and I had a great family, as well as herds of cattle and great flocks of sheep, beyond all who were before me in Jerusalem.
Ecclesiastes 2:8	I amassed for myself silver and gold, and the wealth of kings and governors. I chose men and women singers, and the delights of the sons of men, bowls and pitchers for the purpose of pouring wine.
Ecclesiastes 2:9	And I surpassed in opulence all who were before me in Jerusalem. My wisdom also persevered with me.
Ecclesiastes 2:10	And all that my eyes desired, I did not refuse them. Neither did I prohibit my heart from enjoying every pleasure, and from amusing itself in the things that I had prepared. And I regarded this as my share, as if I were making use of my own labors.
Ecclesiastes 2:11	But when I turned myself toward all the works that my hands had made, and to the labors in which I had perspired to no purpose, I saw emptiness and affliction of the soul in all things, and that nothing is permanent under the sun.
Ecclesiastes 2:12	I continued on, so as to contemplate wisdom, as well as error and foolishness. “What is man,” I said, “that he would be able to follow his Maker, the King?”
Ecclesiastes 2:13	And I saw that wisdom surpasses foolishness, so much so that they differ as much as light from darkness.
Ecclesiastes 2:14	The eyes of a wise man are in his head. A foolish man walks in darkness. Yet I learned that one would pass away like the other.
Ecclesiastes 2:15	And I said in my heart: “If the death of both the foolish and myself will be one, how does it benefit me, if I have given myself more thoroughly to the work of wisdom?” And as I was speaking within my own mind, I perceived that this, too, is emptiness.
Ecclesiastes 2:16	For there will not be a remembrance in perpetuity of the wise, nor of the foolish. And the future times will cover everything together, with oblivion. The learned die in a manner similar to the unlearned.
Ecclesiastes 2:17	And, because of this, my life wearied me, since I saw that everything under the sun is evil, and everything is empty and an affliction of the spirit.
Ecclesiastes 2:18	Again, I detested all my efforts, by which I had earnestly labored under the sun, to be taken up by an heir after me,
Ecclesiastes 2:19	though I know not whether he will be wise or foolish. And yet he will have power over my labors, in which I have toiled and been anxious. And is there anything else so empty?
Ecclesiastes 2:20	Therefore, I ceased, and my heart renounced further laboring under the sun.
Ecclesiastes 2:21	For when someone labors in wisdom, and doctrine, and prudence, he leaves behind what he has obtained to one who is idle. So this, too, is emptiness and a great burden.
Ecclesiastes 2:22	For how can a man benefit from all his labor and affliction of spirit, by which he has been tormented under the sun?
Ecclesiastes 2:23	All his days have been filled with sorrows and hardships; neither does he rest his mind, even in the night. And is this not emptiness?
Ecclesiastes 2:24	Is it not better to eat and drink, and to show his soul the good things of his labors? And this is from the hand of God.
Ecclesiastes 2:25	So who will feast and overflow with delights as much as I have?
Ecclesiastes 2:26	God has given, to the man who is good in his sight, wisdom, and knowledge, and rejoicing. But to the sinner, he has given affliction and needless worrying, so as to add, and to gather, and to deliver, to him who has pleased God. But this, too, is emptiness and a hollow worrying of the mind.
Ecclesiastes 3:1	All things have their time, and all things under heaven continue during their interval.
Ecclesiastes 3:2	A time to be born, and a time to die. A time to plant, and a time to pull up what was planted.
Ecclesiastes 3:3	A time to kill, and a time to heal. A time to tear down, and a time to build up.
Ecclesiastes 3:4	A time to weep, and a time to laugh. A time to mourn, and a time to dance.
Ecclesiastes 3:5	A time to scatter stones, and a time to gather. A time to embrace, and a time to be far from embraces.
Ecclesiastes 3:6	A time to gain, and a time to lose. A time to keep, and a time to cast away.
Ecclesiastes 3:7	A time to rend, and a time to sew. A time to be silent, and a time to speak.
Ecclesiastes 3:8	A time of love, and a time of hatred. A time of war, and a time of peace.
Ecclesiastes 3:9	What more does a man have from his labor?
Ecclesiastes 3:10	I have seen the affliction that God has given to the sons of men, in order that they may be occupied by it.
Ecclesiastes 3:11	He has made all things good in their time, and he has handed over the world to their disputes, so that man may not discover the work which God made from the beginning, even until the end.
Ecclesiastes 3:12	And I realize that there is nothing better than to rejoice, and to do well in this life.
Ecclesiastes 3:13	For this is a gift from God: when each man eats and drinks, and sees the good results of his labor.
Ecclesiastes 3:14	I have learned that all the works which God has made continue on, in perpetuity. We are not able to add anything, nor to take anything away, from those things which God has made in order that he may be feared.
Ecclesiastes 3:15	What has been made, the same continues. What is in the future, has already existed. And God restores what has passed away.
Ecclesiastes 3:16	I saw under the sun: instead of judgment, impiety, and instead of justice, iniquity.
Ecclesiastes 3:17	And I said in my heart: “God will judge the just and the impious, and then the time for each matter shall be.”
Ecclesiastes 3:18	I said in my heart, about the sons of men, that God would test them, and reveal them to be like wild animals.
Ecclesiastes 3:19	For this reason, the passing away of man and of beasts is one, and the condition of both is equal. For as a man dies, so also do they die. All things breathe similarly, and man has nothing more than beast; for all these are subject to vanity.
Ecclesiastes 3:20	And all things continue on to one place; for from the earth they were made, and unto the earth they shall return together.
Ecclesiastes 3:21	Who knows if the spirit of the sons of Adam ascend upward, and if the spirit of the beasts descend downward?
Ecclesiastes 3:22	And I have discovered nothing to be better than for a man to rejoice in his work: for this is his portion. And who shall add to him, so that he may know the things that will occur after him?
Ecclesiastes 4:1	I turned myself to other things, and I saw the false accusations which are carried out under the sun, and the tears of the innocent, and that there was no one to console them; and that they were not able to withstand their violence, being destitute of all help.
Ecclesiastes 4:2	And so, I praised the dead more than the living.
Ecclesiastes 4:3	And happier than both of these, I judged him to be, who has not yet been born, and who has not yet seen the evils which are done under the sun.
Ecclesiastes 4:4	Again, I was contemplating all the labors of men. And I took notice that their endeavors are open to the envy of their neighbor. And so, in this, too, there is emptiness and superfluous anxiety.
Ecclesiastes 4:5	The foolish man folds his hands together, and he consumes his own flesh, saying:
Ecclesiastes 4:6	“A handful with rest is better than both hands filled with labors and with affliction of the soul.”
Ecclesiastes 4:7	While considering this, I also discovered another vanity under the sun.
Ecclesiastes 4:8	He is one, and he does not have a second: no son, no brother. And yet he does not cease to labor, nor are his eyes satisfied with wealth, nor does he reflect, saying: “For whom do I labor and cheat my soul of good things?” In this, too, is emptiness and a most burdensome affliction.
Ecclesiastes 4:9	Therefore, it is better for two to be together, than for one to be alone. For they have the advantage of their companionship.
Ecclesiastes 4:10	If one falls, he shall be supported by the other. Woe to one who is alone. For when he falls, he has no one to lift him up.
